abstract.para: Administration is easier when you understand unit files when working with &systemd;. Unit files use a simple declarative syntax that allows you to see easily, the purpose and effects of a unit upon activation. Unit files have sections with directives, for example:

topic.para: Unit files include the following sections:

listitem.para: The first section found in most unit files is the [Unit] section. This section is used to define the metadata of the unit file and configure the relationship of the unit file to other unit files. This section if usually placed at the top because it provides an overview of the unit file.

The [Service] section provides configuration that is only applicable for services. You must specify Type= in the [Service] section. This categorizes services by their process and daemon behavior. It instructs &systemd; how to correctly manage the service and also determine its state.

This is often the last section in the unit file and is optional. This section is used to define the behavior of a unit file when it is enabled or disabled. When you enable a unit file, it automatically starts at boot.
